description: Indicates cases with differing legal interpretations across jurisdictions, showing where jurisprudence has taken different paths on similar issues

jurisdictions.description: List of jurisdictions with divergent interpretations

reason.description: Explanation of why the interpretations differ
examples: Different constitutional frameworks for emergency powers
Different historical context and legislative intent

point_of_divergence.description: Specific legal issue or principle where divergence occurs
examples: Scope of judicial review during emergency
Definition of 'public interest' in land acquisition
Application of rule against double jeopardy

legal_basis.description: Legal basis for the divergence (constitutional provision, statute, precedent)

divergence_date.description: Date when the divergence was first recognized or occurred

reconciliation_attempted.description: Whether any attempt has been made to reconcile the divergent interpretations

reconciliation_case_id.description: Case that attempted or achieved reconciliation, if any

notes.description: Additional context or scholarly commentary on the divergence

indexes: CREATE INDEX diverges_jurisdictions IF NOT EXISTS FOR ()-[r:DIVERGES_FROM]-() ON (r.jurisdictions)
CREATE INDEX diverges_severity IF NOT EXISTS FOR ()-[r:DIVERGES_FROM]-() ON (r.severity)

examples.description: Bangladesh diverges from India on sedition law interpretation

properties.reason: Different approach to balancing free speech against national security in post-colonial context
properties.point_of_divergence: Threshold for establishing seditious intent and requirement of actual incitement to violence
properties.notes: Bangladesh court took more restrictive view requiring clear and present danger, while Indian court emphasized constitutional limits on sedition charges
